Introduction

Primary ovarian insufficiency (POI) is characterized by insufficient ovarian function associated with elevated FSH levels (ie, hypergonadotropic hypogonadism) in women age <40.  POI typically presents with abnormal uterine bleeding or amenorrhea, infertility, and symptoms of estrogen deficiency similar to those experienced during menopause.

Pathogenesis and risk factors



Ovarian function (ie, hormone production, ovulation) requires functioning ovarian follicles.  Ovarian follicles naturally undergo depletion with increasing age.  In most women, they are completely depleted by age 51, the average age of menopause.



Patients with POI lose ovarian function sooner (ie, age <40); the most common pathogenesis is the accelerated depletion of primordial follicles (

figure 1
).  In most patients, the cause of accelerated follicle depletion is idiopathic; however, several risk factors and underlying causes have been identified, including:



  • Prior ovarian surgery, chemotherapy, or pelvic radiation (ie, damage to follicles)
  • Genetic abnormalities
    • Turner syndrome (45,X) (
      figure 2
      )
    • Fragile X syndrome premutation
    • Other X chromosome abnormalities
  • Family history of POI
  • Autoimmune oophoritis (ie, lymphocytic infiltration of theca cells)
  • Personal or family history of autoimmune disorders (eg, autoimmune thyroid disease, autoimmune adrenal insufficiency)
  • Galactosemia, likely due to toxic effects of galactose metabolites on the ovaries


Once all follicles are depleted, the ovary no longer ovulates or produces estrogens, inhibin, or androgens.  This hypogonadism leads to abnormal uterine bleeding or amenorrhea, infertility, and signs of estrogen deficiency (eg, vaginal dryness).  The loss of estrogen and inhibin production (ie, loss of negative feedback control on the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian [HPO] axis (

figure 3
)) causes an increase in GnRH, FSH, and LH characteristic of hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

Clinical presentation



The presenting symptoms of POI are similar to those of menopause:



  • Menstrual irregularities (eg, abnormal uterine bleeding, amenorrhea), which may not be identified until hormonal contraception is discontinued (due to masking of the irregularities)
  • Symptoms of estrogen deficiency (
    figure 4
    )
    • Vasomotor symptoms: hot flashes, flushing, night sweats
    • Genitourinary symptoms: vaginal dryness (ie, atrophic vaginitis), dyspareunia
    • Sexual dysfunction and decreased libido
    • CNS symptoms: sleep disturbances, fatigue, difficulty concentrating
  • Infertility (anovulation due to follicle depletion)


Some patients with POI have intermittent ovarian function and occasional ovulatory menstrual cycles; accordingly, such patients may lack overt symptoms of estrogen deficiency.



On physical examination, atrophic vaginitis may be seen.  Patients with autoimmune oophoritis may have enlarged ovaries.  Otherwise, the examination is typically normal unless another related condition is present (eg, Turner syndrome [eg, short stature, shield chest], Hashimoto thyroiditis [eg, goiter], autoimmune adrenal insufficiency [eg, increased skin pigmentation, orthostatic hypotension]).

Diagnosis



All patients presenting with new-onset menstrual irregularities require a standardized evaluation, including:



  • Pregnancy test
  • Serum FSH level
  • Serum TSH and prolactin levels (because thyroid disorders and prolactinemia are common causes of irregular menses)


POI can be definitively diagnosed in patients with menstrual irregularities (eg, abnormal uterine bleeding, amenorrhea) and elevated serum FSH in the postmenopausal range.  A low serum estradiol also supports the diagnosis.  Imaging (eg, pelvic ultrasonography) is not required for diagnosis, although it is commonly performed in the evaluation of amenorrhea and infertility.  Patients typically have unremarkable findings, but those with autoimmune oophoritis may have enlarged, cystic ovaries.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis for POI includes other causes of menstrual irregularities (eg, abnormal uterine bleeding, secondary amenorrhea).



  • Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea:  causes menstrual irregularities and estrogen deficiency.  However, FSH is low (ie, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism).
  • Hyperprolactinemia:  can cause amenorrhea, but prolactin is elevated and FSH levels are low because prolactin inhibits hypothalamic GnRH production.
  • Thyroid disease:  hypothyroidism can cause menstrual irregularities; however, TSH is high, FSH is low, and with no signs of estrogen deficiency.  FSH is low because low T3/T4 increases thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH), which stimulates prolactin production.  Prolactin inhibits GnRH production, leading to low FSH.
  • Asherman syndrome (ie, intrauterine adhesions):  can cause menstrual irregularities and infertility, but estrogen and FSH levels are normal.
  • Sheehan syndrome (ie, pituitary ischemia):  can cause amenorrhea, but patients typically have low FSH and low levels of other pituitary hormones (ie, panhypopituitarism).
  • Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS):  can cause menstrual irregularities and anovulatory infertility; however, estrogen and FSH levels are usually normal.

Management



Once POI is diagnosed, multiple issues must be addressed, including:

Treatment for hypogonadism



  • Estrogen therapy is recommended unless there is an absolute contraindication (eg, venous thromboembolism).  In patients with a uterus, a progestin is added to prevent endometrial cancer.
  • Estrogen treats symptoms of estrogen deficiency and reduces the risks of osteoporosis and cardiovascular disease.
  • Treatment is continued until age 50-51, the average age of natural menopause.

Evaluation for underlying causes and coexisting conditions



  • Genetic testing (eg, karyotyping, FMR1 premutation testing)
  • Adrenal antibody testing due to increased risk for autoimmune adrenal insufficiency, a potentially life-threatening disorder
  • TSH and thyroid-peroxidase autoantibody testing due to increased risk for autoimmune thyroid disease
  • Bone mineral density testing to assess for osteoporosis

Additional management



  • Fertility counseling (eg, donor oocyte, donor embryo transfer) for patients desiring pregnancy
  • Calcium, vitamin D, and weight-bearing exercise to decrease the risk for osteoporosis

Summary



Primary ovarian insufficiency (POI) (
